title: Best and Worst States for Allergies

content: When you’re dealing with sneezing, congestion, and watery eyes, you may not be thinking about your ZIP code. However, where you live greatly affects how you feel when allergy season rolls around.

sections.heading: Allergies for All
content: Allergies happen when your body’s immune system reacts to an allergen such as pollen, pet dander, or mold. They’re one of the most common medical conditions, causing millions of people to reach for tissues and eye drops each year to manage symptoms. Symptoms are worse for people in certain regions of the U.S. due to high pollen counts, large amounts of trees and flowers, or other factors in the environment. For the past 20 years, the Asthma and Allergy Foundation of America (AAFA) has produced an annual list of the best and worst cities and states for those with allergies. The list considers the 100 most populated cities. These states are on the list based on several factors including: The scores for trees, grass, and weed pollen The amount of over-the-counter allergy medicine use The number of board-certified allergy doctors in the area Common allergy triggers that are often different in certain parts of the country include: Tree pollen (early spring) Grass pollen (spring and summer) Ragweed pollen (fall) Dust mites and cockroach droppings (year-round) Dander from pets (can be year-round but might cause worse symptoms in winter, when houses are closed up) Spores from indoor and outdoor fungi and molds (seasonal and year-round)

sections.heading: The Worst Cities for Allergies
content: Here are the top 10 cities that create the biggest challenge if you have allergies based on data from the AAFA. Wichita, Kansas Virginia Beach, Virginia Greenville, South Carolina Dallas, Texas Oklahoma City, Oklahoma Tulsa, Oklahoma Richmond, Virginia Des Moines, Iowa Raleigh, North Carolina Fayetteville, Arkansas Wichita, Kansas, made the top of the list for the second year in a row due to higher-than-average tree and grass pollen and few board-certified allergy doctors in the area. Windy, flat cities with lots of pollen like Dallas also make the list.

sections.heading: What Can Be Done?
content: Before calling the movers, there are some things you can do if you live in one of the cities that are rough for people with allergies: Schedule outdoor activities on low pollen days. When you’re outside, wear hats, sunglasses, and other coverings to keep the pollen out of your hair and eyes. Take your shoes off before coming inside. Wash your bedding regularly. Change clothes after time outdoors. Keep your windows closed during peak pollen times (early mornings and late evenings are normally OK). Wipe off pets when they come inside and bathe them regularly. Use HEPA allergy-friendly air filters for your HVAC system. Consider buying an air filter/purifier for your home. Vacuum and clean floors and fabric furniture at least weekly. Clean window treatments (blinds and curtains) and rugs at least once a month.

sections.heading: The Best Cities for Allergies
content: According to the AAFA, the best cities to live if you have allergies are: Akron, Ohio Albuquerque, New Mexico Madison, Wisconsin San Jose, California Cleveland, Ohio Phoenix, Arizona Sacramento, California Stockton, California Tucson, Arizona Bakersfield, California The best places to live aren’t surprisingly in the desert Southwest (low vegetation and plants) and the Great Lakes (plenty of rain to wash away pollen). But "best place to live" for one person may not be the best place for another. It depends on your type of allergies. For example, if you have springtime allergies due to tree pollen, you might do better in dryer climates with fewer trees like in the Southwestern U.S. Allergies from grass pollen are seen in the late spring and early summer in warmer climates like Texas and California. While most cities in these states aren’t on the high-allergy list, many people still notice symptoms during this time of year. The culprit? Pollen from grasses such as Bermuda, Fescue, and Kentucky Blue. Ragweed pollen – which can be found across the country – is the top offender. One in seven people are allergic to it. Ragweed is increasing in the Eastern and Midwestern parts of the U.S.

sections.heading: Climate Shifts and Allergies
content: Studies show temperatures are increasing across the country. Because of this, growing and pollen seasons start earlier and last longer. Some states now have pollen from trees, grass, or weeds year-round. Higher temperatures also trap heat in urban areas, raising pollution and pollen counts. Pollen and warmer temperatures go hand-in-hand.

sections.heading: The Long-Term Impact
content: Seasonal allergies are more than annoying. Over time, they can impact your health in more ways: Reduced quality of life. Allergy symptoms cause many people to miss school or work. It can put a big dent in your daily routine and productivity. Poor sleep. Hay fever symptoms can keep you awake or make it hard to stay asleep. This can lead to fatigue and a lowered immune system (which can make it easier to get sick). Worsening asthma. If you already have asthma, allergies can make it worse and ramp up symptoms like coughing and wheezing. Sinusitis. Left untreated, allergies can lead to a sinus infection and inflammation of the sinuses. This requires stronger treatment and possibly more time off work. Ear infection. Children with seasonal allergies are more likely to get a middle ear infection .

sections.heading: Who Is Affected Most by Allergies?
content: Unfortunately, anyone who breathes the air (and pollen or dust) around them can be subject to allergies. In 2021, studies showed that about 81 million people in the U.S. had seasonal allergies (or hay fever). This number included 67 million adults and 14 million children. But allergy symptoms do impact some people more than others: Black children and non-Hispanic White children were more likely to have a seasonal allergy than Hispanic and Asian children. They’re more common in boys than girls. They’re more common in women than men. They’re higher in adults of mixed race, especially adults who are half Black and half White.

sections.heading: Allergies and Asthma
content: Many people have both asthma and allergies with one triggering symptoms for the other. The symptoms (wheezing, shortness of breath, coughing, and waking up at night) tend to be higher in children. Most people will outgrow this condition, known as allergic asthma, but not always. Check with your doctor if your symptoms aren’t getting better. Uncontrolled asthma can lead to a medical emergency.

sections.heading: Allergy Treatments
content: Allergies are treated in four main ways: Avoiding the things that cause your allergies. Staying away from allergy triggers may involve moving states or avoiding being outside when pollen counts are high. Allergy medication. Antihistamines are the most common allergy medications and are available over-the-counter or as a prescription. They block a chemical called histamine in the body which causes allergic reactions – sneezing, a runny nose, itchy, watery eyes, and hives. These meds can be taken as needed, but many doctors will recommend daily use (starting before allergy season) for best effects. Note: Some of these medications, like Benadryl, may make you drowsy, so be careful driving or working after taking them. Also, check with your doctor if you’re pregnant or nursing. Drugs like Allegra, Claritin, and Zyrtec may cause less drowsiness. Nasal steroid sprays. Nasal steroid sprays help prevent and calm inflammation in your nasal tissues and airways. Like antihistamines, they are available over the counter or by prescription. Doctors also suggest using these a few weeks before allergy season starts or year-round to help ease your symptoms of congestion, sneezing, runny nose and watery eyes. Using nasal sprays correctly is key. Follow the instructions on the package or ask your health care team for a demo to be sure.

sections.heading: Immunotherapy.
content: Some people may need allergy shots for their symptoms. This treatment may come in liquid form for children. It may also be a tablet dissolved under your tongue. It includes small amounts of allergens to teach your body not to overreact to allergy triggers. These are typically given over several years. For severe allergies, you might need something called epinephrine. This helps if you have severe breathing issues. Your doctor will let you know if you need to carry it with you at all times. Ask them about when you might need to go to the ER in certain cases. A word on allergy treatments Some research studies suggest long-term use of older antihistamines like Benadryl is linked to memory loss. This may not be a problem for everyone, so check with your doctor to see if this is something you should avoid.

sections.heading: Traveling to States With High Allergens
content: Eventually, most of us have to leave the comfort of our homes (even in allergy-friendly states) and travel to other states for work or to visit family or friends. What can you do during temporary times in states that have higher pollen counts, strong winds, or other things that can trigger allergies?

content_blocks.text: Eventually, most of us have to leave the comfort of our homes (even in allergy-friendly states) and travel to other states for work or to visit family or friends. What can you do during temporary times in states that have higher pollen counts, strong winds, or other things that can trigger allergies?

content: Before your trip: Refill any prescription allergy medications. Pick up any over-the-county allergy meds or supplies. If staying at a hotel, request an allergy-friendly room (includes special bedding and air filters) if available. Ask the hotel for a nonsmoking, mold-free, pet-free room. Read online reviews too. During your trip: Pack a mask during flu season or in case you’re seated next to pets or other irritants (strong perfume, dust, etc.). Be kind to yourself. Stress is a trigger for those with allergies.

sections.heading: Do I have allergies or a cold?
content: Experts now know that male trees produce pollen and female trees produce seeds. Several cities are now working to balance the community with more female trees. Reach out to your local arbor group to find out how to volunteer. The symptoms look (and feel) the same – sneezing, coughing, congestion, feeling tired, and having headaches. But there are key differences. Colds typically pop up during winter/colder months while allergies are often seasonal or in the spring. A cold may come with a fever and yellowish mucus when you blow your nose (versus clear if it’s allergies). When in doubt, check it out. Contact your doctor to settle the matter and get the right treatment. How are allergies diagnosed? Your doctor will do a physical exam, ask about your medical history, and likely do a skin test and blood test to see how allergens are impacting your body.

sections.heading: Is there a cure for allergies?
How else can I make the world a more allergy-friendly place?
content: Currently, there is no cure for allergies. However, there are more treatments than in prior years. Consider joining a clinical trial. The information gathered from clinical trials allows experts to create new treatments, update current treatments, and learn about how treatments and lifestyle changes impact different types of people. Contact your doctor or allergist if you’re interested in signing up.
